case_name: M/s Johri Mal Prahlad Rai v. M/s Tirhut Umbrella Works

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 268 of 1960 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 268 of 1960. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 5, 1958, of the Patna High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 252/55.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 5, 1958, of the Patna High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 252/55. V. Viswanatha Sastri, Yogeshwar Prasad and U. P. Singh,

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on November 13, 1962 by SHAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. November 13. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-M s. johri Mal Prahald Rai-hereing after referred to as the plaintiffs-commenced an action against

facts.text: Plaintiffs Ms. Johri Mal Prahlad Rai commenced suit against Ms. Tirhut Umbrella Works in City Civil Court, Bombay for Rs. 20,320/- with costs and interest.

anchor.surface_text: M s. johri Mal Prahald Rai-hereing after referred to as the plaintiffs-commenced an action against M s. Tirhut Umbrella Works  a firm carrying on business at Laheriasarai in the State of Bihar  in the City Civil Court, Bombay, for a decree for Rs. 20,320/- with companyts and interest.

facts.text: Ms. Tirhut Umbrella Works is a firm carrying on business at Laheriasarai in the State of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: against M s. Tirhut Umbrella Works  a firm carrying on business at Laheriasarai in the State of Bihar  in the City Civil Court, Bombay, for a decree for Rs. 20,320/- with

facts.text: Summons served upon Gajendra Narain Singh at Road 8, R Block at Patna, Bihar as a partner of the defendant firm.

anchor.surface_text: Summons of the suit was served upon one Gajendra Narain Singh-hereinafter referred to as Singh-at Road 8, R Block at Patna  Bihar  as a partner of the defendant firm.

facts.text: Mr. D. B. Tilak, engaged by Singh, filed Vakalatnama signed by Singh on April 22, 1953 authorizing him to act, appear and plead.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. D. B. Tilak an advocate who was engaged by Singh, filed on April 22, 1953 in the Court a Vakalatmama signed by Singh authorising him to act, appear and plead in the suit.

facts.text: Chamber summons for directions served on Singh.

anchor.surface_text: A chamber summons for directions for trial of the suit as a companymercial cause was thereafter served on Singh.

facts.text: On September 9, 1953, Mr. Tilak addressed a letter to plaintiffs' attorneys requesting adjournment to file written statement.

anchor.surface_text: On September 9, 1953 Mr. Tilak a, advocate for Singh addressed a letter to the Attorneys of the plaintiffs requesting them to companysent to an adjournment of the x x x suit to enable Singh to file his written statement.

facts.text: Chamber summons adjourned by consent for a fortnight.

anchor.surface_text: By companysent of the advocates the chamber summons for directions stood adjourned by order of the Court for a fortnight.

facts.text: On September 24, 1953, Mr. Tilak informed court that Singh claimed not to be a partner and prayed for withdrawal of appearance.

anchor.surface_text: When the chamber summons for directions was taken up for hearing on September 24, 1953 Mr. Tilak informed the Court that his client Singh claimed that he was number a partner of the defendant firm, and orally prayed for an order permitting withdrawal of the appearance filed in Court.

facts.text: City Civil Court declined oral request for withdrawal and directed appropriate proceedings if advised.

anchor.surface_text: The Court declined to accede to the oral request and directed that appropriate proceedings to withdraw the appearance may, if so advised, be taken by Singh.

facts.text: Court directed suit be transferred to commercial causes list and gave directions.

anchor.surface_text: The Court directed that the suit be transferred to the list of companymercial causes and gave directions for the progress of the suit.

facts.text: On November 27, 1953, Mr. Tilak appeared and submitted Singh not partner, prayed withdrawal and adjournment.

anchor.surface_text: When the suit was taken up for hearing before the City Civil Court on November 27, 1953 Mr. Tilak again appeared and submitted that his client on whom summons was served in the suit, was number a partner of the defendant firm and prayed that he be allowed to withdraw the appearance which was filed without protest.

facts.text: City Civil Court rejected application for withdrawal and adjournment; Tilak withdrew with leave; suit heard ex parte.

anchor.surface_text: The Court rejected the application for leave to withdraw the appearance and also rejected the application of Mr. Tilak for an adjournment of the suit. Mr. Tilak then withdrew from the suit with leave of the Court, and the suit was heard ex parte.

facts.text: City Civil Court decreed the suit as prayed, recording evidence and admitting correspondence.

anchor.surface_text: The Court recorded the evidence of a witness for the plaintiffs and admitted certain companyrespondence tendered by the plaintiffs, and decreed the suit as prayed.

facts.text: Decree forwarded by Registrar of City Civil Court, Bombay to District Judge, Patna with certificate of non-satisfaction.

anchor.surface_text: The decree was forwarded by the-Registrar of the City Civil Court, Bombay to the Court of the District Judge, Patna, with a certificate of number-satisfaction.

facts.text: Plaintiffs applied for leave to execute decree against Singh under O. 21, rule 50(2) CPC.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs then applied for leave to execute the decree against Singh under O. 21, rule 50 2  of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: Singh contended he was not a partner, not liable, not served as partner, appeared individually, informed court not partner.

anchor.surface_text: Singh companytended that he was number a partner of the defendant firm and that he was number liable to satisfy the debts of that firm that he was number served with summons in the suit that he had appeared in the suit in which the decree was passed number as a partner, but in his individual capacity and that he had informed the Court that he was number a partner of the defendant firm.

facts.text: Plaintiffs applied for execution without order granting leave.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs then applied for execution of the decree claiming that numberorder of the Court granting leave to execute the decree was necessary.

facts.text: District Judge, Patna on May 12, 1955 held execution could not be against Singh under O.21 r.50(1)(b) or (c), as partnership undecided; found Singh not partner.

anchor.surface_text: The District judge, Patna, by his order dated May 12, 1955 held that the execution companyld number be directed against Singh relying upon sub-clauses  b  or  c  of rule 50, O. 2 1, for the question whether he was a partner of the defendant firm was left undecided by the City Civil Court.

facts.text: Patna High Court reversed District Judge, held plaintiffs entitled to execute under O.21 r.50(1)(b) against Singh.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal against the order of the District.Judge rejecting the application for execution against singh the High Court at Patna had that on the facts proved the plaintiffs were entitled as of right to execute the decree under O. 21 rule 50 1  b  against Singh.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court preferred by Singh with certificate under Art. 133(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accordingly reversed the order passed by the District judge and directed execution to proceed against Singh. With certificate under Art. 133 1  a  granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred by Singh.

facts.text: Supreme Court found Singh served with summons as partner of defendant firm.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on a review of the circumstances arrived at the companyclusion that Singh was served with summons of the suit as a partner of the defendant firm. That companyclusion is amply supported by the evidence,

facts.text: Singh admitted in affidavit and testimony that he was served with summons.

anchor.surface_text: Singh has in his affidavit sworn in the suit, and also in his testimony at the hearing in the execution proceeding admitted that he was served with a summons in the suit,

facts.text: Singh did not enter appearance under protest; filed appearance in individual name.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case Singh did number enter appearance under protest. He filed an appearance in his individual name in the suit, and obtained an adjournment from the Court to enable him to file his written statement.

facts.text: City Civil Court rejected Singh's application to withdraw appearance.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the summons for directions he companytended that he was number a partner of the defendant firm and applied for leave to withdraw his appearance which was filed without protest. Unless the Court permitted Singh to with draw the appearance initially filed,

facts.text: Supreme Court held decree executable against Singh under O.21 r.50(1)(b) as he appeared under rule 6 O.30.

anchor.surface_text: Singh being a person who had after being served as a partner appeared under rule 6, the decree of the City Civil Court, Bombay was executable against him.
With certificate under Art. 133 1  a  granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred by Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Order 30 of the Code of Civil Procedure deals with the manner in which suits may be filed by or against firms.

concepts.unlisted_description: Suits by or against firms and their partners

anchor.surface_text: That rule, in so far As it is material, provides- Where persons are sued as partners in the name of their firm, the summons shall be served either-  a  upon any one or more of the partners, or  b  at the principal place at which the partnership business is carried on within India, upon any person having, at the time of service, the companys trol or management of the partnership business there, as the Court may direct and such service shall be deemed good service upon the firm so sued, whether all or any of the partners are within or without India Provided x x x.

concepts.interpretation: Summons served on Singh as partner constituted good service on the firm

anchor.surface_text: the presumption which arises under rule 5 of O. 30 which provides Where a summons is issued to a firm and is served in the manner provided by rule 3, every person upon whom it is served shall be informed by numberice in writing given at the time of such service, whether he is served as a partner or as a person having the companytrol or management of the partnership business, or in both characters, and, in default of such numberice, the person served shall be deemed to be served as a partner.

concepts.interpretation: In default of notice, person served deemed served as partner; applies to Singh

anchor.surface_text: Rule 8 of O. 30 provides - Any person served with summons as a partner under rule 3 may appear under protest, denying that he is a partner, but such appearance shall number preclude the plaintiff from otherwise serving a summons on the firm and obtaining decree against the firm in default of appearance where numberpartner has appeared.

anchor.surface_text: Order 21 rule5  the Code of Civil Procedure deals with execution of decrees against firms. By cl.  1  it is provided Where a decree has been passed against a firm, execution may be granted-  a  against any property of the partnership  b  against any person who has appeared in his own name under rule 6 of rule 7 of Order XXX or who has admitted on the pleadings that he is, or who has been- adjudged to be, a partner  c  against any person who has been individually served as a partner with a summons and has failed to appear. Provided x x x x x. Clause  2  provides Where the decree-holder claims to be entitled to cause the decree to be executed against any person other than such a person as is referred to in sub-rule  1 , clauses  b  and  c  as being a partner in the firm, he may apply to the Court r which passed the decree or leave, and where the liability is number disputed, such Court may grant such leave, or where such liability is disputed, may order that the liability of such per-son be tried and determined in any manner in which any issue in a suit may be tried and determined. By cl.  3  it is provided Where the liability of any person has been tried and determined under sub-rule  2 , the order made thereon shall have the same force and be subject to the same companyditions as to appeal or otherwise as if it were a decree.

concepts.interpretation: Decree executable against Singh under cl.(1)(b) as he appeared under O.30 r.6 after service as partner; no need for leave under (2)

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: aintiffs did undoubtedly make an application for leave to execute the decree against Singh on the footing that he was a person other than a person ref

anchor.surface_text: This decree against the firm was by virtue of sub-rule  1 cl.  b of rule 50 O. 21, liable to be executed against Singh. The High Court was therefore, in our judgment right in directing execution of the decree of the City Civil Court, Bombay, against Singh.

concepts.interpretation: Plaintiffs entitled to execute under (1)(b) without leave under (2); right not lost by mistaken application

issues.text: Whether Singh was served with summons of the suit as a partner of the defendant firm

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on a review of the circumstances arrived at the conclusion that Singh was served with summons of the suit as a partner of the defendant firm. That conclusion is amply supported by the evidence, and the presumption which arises under rule 5 of O. 30 which provides Where a summons is issued to a firm and is served in the manner provided by rule 3, every person upon whom it is served shall be informed by notice

issues.text: Whether Singh entered appearance under protest denying that he is a partner under Order 30 rule 8

anchor.surface_text: Rule 8 of O. 30 provides - Any person served with summons as a partner under rule 3 may appear under protest, denying that he is a partner, but such appearance shall not preclude the plaintiff from otherwise serving a summons on the firm and obtaining decree against the firm in default of appearance where no partner has appeared.

issues.text: Whether the appearance filed by Singh in his individual name constituted an appearance under rule 6 of Order XXX on behalf of the firm

anchor.surface_text: In the present case Singh did not enter appearance under protest. He filed an appearance in his individual name in the suit, and obtained an adjournment from the Court to enable him to file his written statement. The appearance so filed must be deemed to be on behalf of the firm.

issues.text: Whether execution of the decree against the firm could be directed against Singh relying upon sub-clauses (b) or (c) of rule 50 Order XXI without prior determination of his partnership status

anchor.surface_text: The District judge, Patna, by his order dated May 12, 1955 held that the execution could not be directed against Singh relying upon sub-clauses b or c of rule 50, O. 21, for the question whether he was a partner of the defendant firm was left undecided by the City Civil Court.

issues.text: Whether the plaintiffs were entitled as of right to execute the decree against Singh under Order XXI rule 50(1)(b)

anchor.surface_text: Singh being a person who had after being served as a partner appeared under rule 6, the decree of the City Civil Court, Bombay was executable against him. holdings.text: Singh was served with summons of the suit as a partner of the defendant firm and must be deemed to have been served as a partner under Order XXX rule 5 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on a review of the circumstances arrived at the conclusion that Singh was served with summons of the suit as a partner of the defendant firm. That conclusion is amply supported by the evidence, and the presumption which arises under rule 5 of O. 30 which provides Where a summons is issued to a firm and is served in the manner provided by rule 3, every person upon whom it is served shall be informed by notice

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court conclusion supported by evidence, presumption under O.30 r.5 in default of notice, Singh's admission of service, and counsel's concession.

holdings.text: Singh did not enter appearance under protest denying he is a partner as permitted by Order XXX rule 8 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 8 of O. 30 provides - Any person served with summons as a partner under rule 3 may appear under protest, denying that he is a partner, but such appearance shall not preclude the plaintiff from otherwise serving a summons on the firm and obtaining decree against the firm in default of appearance where no partner has appeared.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Singh filed appearance in individual name without protest and sought adjournment to file written statement; later oral contentions insufficient.

holdings.text: The appearance filed by Singh in his individual name must be deemed to be on behalf of the firm under Order XXX rule 6 CPC and continued as such after rejection of withdrawal application.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case Singh did not enter appearance under protest. He filed an appearance in his individual name in the suit, and obtained an adjournment from the Court to enable him to file his written statement. The appearance so filed must be deemed to be on behalf of the firm.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Filed without protest after service as partner; court rejection of withdrawal means appearance continued under r.6 on behalf of firm.

holdings.text: Execution of the decree against the firm can be granted against Singh under Order XXI rule 50(1)(b) CPC without prior determination of actual partnership status.

anchor.surface_text: Order 21 rule 50 the Code of Civil Procedure deals with execution of decrees against firms. By cl. 1 it is provided Where a decree has been passed against a firm, execution may be granted- a against any property of the partnership b against any person who has appeared in his own name under rule 6 or rule 7 of Order XXX or who has admitted on the pleadings that he is, or who has been- adjudged to be, a partner c against any person who has been individually served as a partner with a summons and has failed to appear.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Satisfies conditions of (1)(b) by service as partner and appearance under O.30 r.6; no adjudication of partnership required for this clause.

holdings.text: Plaintiffs entitled as of right to execute the decree against Singh under Order XXI rule 50(1)(b) CPC.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal against the order of the District.Judge rejecting the application for execution against singh the High Court at Patna held that on the facts proved the plaintiffs were entitled as of right to execute the decree under O. 21 rule 50 1 b against Singh.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Singh served as partner and appeared under O.30 r.6; falls squarely within (1)(b); High Court correctly held entitled as of right.

holdings.text: Plaintiffs' right to execute under Order XXI rule 50(1)(b) CPC was not lost by their mistaken initial application for leave under sub-rule (2).

anchor.surface_text: Singh being a person who had after being served as a partner appeared under rule 6, the decree of the City Civil Court, Bombay was executable against him. The plaintiffs did undoubtedly make an application for leave to execute the decree against Singh on the footing that he was a person other than a person referred to in cls. b and c of sub-rule 1 of r. 50 O. 21,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mistaken application under (2) due to incorrect appreciation; right under (1)(b) persists and can be pursued by abandoning (2) application.

holdings.text: The decree against the firm was by virtue of Order XXI rule 50(1)(b) liable to be executed against Singh; High Court right in directing execution against him.

anchor.surface_text: This decree against the firm was by virtue of sub-rule 1 cl. b of rule 50 O. 21, liable to be executed against Singh. The High Court was therefore, in our judgment right in directing execution of the decree of the City Civil Court, Bombay, against Singh.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Record establishes service as partner, appearance under O.30 r.6, rejected withdrawal; directly applies O.21 r.50(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore, in our judgment right in directing execution of the decree of the City Civil Court, Bombay, against Singh.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court order upheld directing execution of the decree against Singh

anchor.surface_text: s appeal has been preferred by Singh. Order 30 of the Code of Civil Procedure deals with the manner in which suits may be filed by or against firms. T

edges.explanation: Holding directly addresses and resolves the issue of whether Singh was served as a partner

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on a review of the circumstances arrived at the conclusion that Singh was served with summons of the suit as a partner of the defendant firm. That conclusion is amply supported by the evidence, and the presumption which arises under rule 5 of O. 30 which provides Where a summons is issued to a firm and is served in the manner provided by rule 3, every person upon whom it is served shall be informed by notice
The High Court was therefore, in our judgment right in directing execution of the decree of the City Civil Court, Bombay, against Singh.
erved with summons of the suit as a partner of the defendant firm. That companyclusion is amply supported by the evidence, and the presumption which a

edges.explanation: Holding states Singh did not enter appearance under protest denying partnership as per Order XXX Rule 8, directly addressing the issue

anchor.surface_text: Rule 8 of O. 30 provides - Any person served with summons as a partner under rule 3 may appear under protest, denying that he is a partner, but such appearance shall not preclude the plaintiff from otherwise serving a summons on the firm and obtaining decree against the firm in default of appearance where no partner has appeared.
The High Court was therefore, in our judgment right in directing execution of the decree of the City Civil Court, Bombay, against Singh.
t permitted Singh to with draw the appearance initially filed, it companytinued to be an appearance under rule 6 of O. XXX on behalf of the firm. We a

edges.explanation: Holding directly addresses whether individual appearance constituted appearance under rule 6 on behalf of firm

anchor.surface_text: In the present case Singh did not enter appearance under protest. He filed an appearance in his individual name in the suit, and obtained an adjournment from the Court to enable him to file his written statement. The appearance so filed must be deemed to be on behalf of the firm.
The High Court was therefore, in our judgment right in directing execution of the decree of the City Civil Court, Bombay, against Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Order 21 rule 50 the Code of Civil Procedure deals with execution of decrees against firms. By cl. 1 it is provided Where a decree has been passed against a firm, execution may be granted- a against any property of the partnership b against any person who has appeared in his own name under rule 6 or rule 7 of Order XXX or who has admitted on the pleadings that he is, or who has been- adjudged to be, a partner c against any person who has been individually served as a partner with a summons and has failed to appear.
The High Court was therefore, in our judgment right in directing execution of the decree of the City Civil Court, Bombay, against Singh.

edges.explanation: Holding of entitlement as of right under (1)(b) supports that such right was not subsequently lost.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal against the order of the District.Judge rejecting the application for execution against singh the High Court at Patna held that on the facts proved the plaintiffs were entitled as of right to execute the decree under O. 21 rule 50 1 b against Singh.
The High Court was therefore, in our judgment right in directing execution of the decree of the City Civil Court, Bombay, against Singh.

The High Court was therefore, in our judgment right in directing execution of the decree of the City Civil Court, Bombay, against Singh.
